children.contents: Determine the number of degree 2 polynomials $ Q(x) $ such that $ P(Q(x)) $ is divisible by $ P(x) $.
children.original_response:
To solve the problem, we need to analyze the functional equation $ P(Q(x)) = P(x) \cdot R(x) $, where $ P(x) = (x-1)(x-2)(x-3) $ and $ R(x) $ is a polynomial of degree 3.

The first step is to understand the degree of the polynomials involved. Since $ P(x) $ is a degree 3 polynomial, and $ Q(x) $ is an unknown polynomial, $ P(Q(x)) $ will be a polynomial of degree $ 3 \cdot \deg(Q(x)) $. On the right-hand side, $ P(x) \cdot R(x) $ is a product of a degree 3 polynomial and a degree 3 polynomial, so it will be a polynomial of degree 6.

Thus, we equate the degrees:
$$
3 \cdot \deg(Q(x)) = 6 \Rightarrow \deg(Q(x)) = 2.
$$

So $ Q(x) $ must be a degree 2 polynomial.

[OUTPUT] Determine the number of degree 2 polynomials $ Q(x) $ such that $ P(Q(x)) $ is divisible by $ P(x) $.
